analysis.lecture_title: Hydrostatic Pressure and Free-Surface Shapes in Linearly Accelerated and Rotating Containers
analysis.lecture_summary: The lecture derives how body acceleration (linear or rotational) modifies hydrostatic pressure and the shape of the free surface in containers. It shows how to obtain pressure gradients in an accelerating frame, how the free surface tilts under linear acceleration, and how a rotating fluid develops a parabolic free-surface profile. The notes also apply these results to compute heights, submerged volumes, centroids, and the critical rotation rate for spilling, with geometric volume calculations for truncated and parabolic segments.
core_topics: Hydrostatic pressure gradient under linear acceleration
Tilted free surface and slope relation to acceleration
Integration of pressure to find surface height distributions
Geometric volume and centroid calculations for sloped/truncated containers
Pressure field in a rotating (centrifugal) frame
Parabolic free-surface shape in rotating fluids
Volume of paraboloid segment and submerged volume calculations
Unit discussion for volumetric flow (Q, m3/s, liters)
learning_objectives: derive the hydrostatic pressure gradient in a container subject to a constant linear acceleration
explain and compute the slope of a free surface produced by linear acceleration
apply hydrostatic integration to determine heights and submerged volumes in nonuniform container geometries
derive the pressure distribution in a rotating fluid using cylindrical coordinates
show that a rotating free surface is a paraboloid and compute its radial height profile
calculate the volume and centroid of a parabolic free-surface segment and use this to find conditions for overflow
determine the critical angular speed that causes fluid to spill from a rotating container
convert and reason about common volumetric flow units (m3/s, L/s, gallons/min)
assumed_prerequisites: classical mechanics (constant acceleration and rotation concepts)
familiarity with cylindrical coordinates and basic geometry
